author: sproul
content: fcU = forkchoiceUpdated, it's the message sent from the consensus layer to the execution layer to tell it "hey this is the head now" and _optionally_ "I want you to start building a block"

author: nishant0
content: There is also the other issue on getting your execution peering right. If you do not have enough peers on your execution node, much smaller amounts of txs will be gossiped to you. The side effect is that your local mempool has a much smaller set of transactions to include

author: wslyvh
content: Hmm, interesting. Seeing Etherscan's mempool, I assumed there would always be more than enough pending txs to fill any block. You think that's less for smaller/less connected clients?

author: ralexstokes
content: in general there are, and if anything why we care about scaling R&D -- but these transactions do not magically materialize in your local node and must be transmitted to you from a peer; in which case if you don't have good connectivity to the enough of the network, you are likely to only see a subset of the transactions everyone else sees

author: ralexstokes
content: my intuition here (which could be off) is that most nodes get most transactions pretty quickly so the strange cases of small/empty blocks you found are more due to processing bottlenecks/bugs than due to some kind of sparse mempool

author: potuz
content: I really don't think it's the case. The mempool does not fill blocks all the time, so If geth freezes the mempool at the time you call FCU, then if the last proposer is late and has wiped the pool and you call FCU right before proposing, there's not much the El can pack. My node didn't change anything and went from 1-5% to 50% right after the fix
